awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference: SaTC: CORE: 2.0 Vision Proposal
awd_abstract_narration:
NSF SaTC (Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace) program has provided a steady support of innovative research, education, and transition to practice projects over the past decade. However, the cyber security research front has continuously moved forward with recent developments in internet of things, artificial intelligence, social media, quantum computing in a post-covid world, requiring a rethinking of future directions. and a new investment strategy and investment priorities of the NSF SaTC program. This proposal outlines the background, structure, and timeline for the SaTC 2.0 strategic planning activity, as well as the development of a SaTC 2.0 vision document. The effort will begin with pre-planning and information gathering activities, followed by a multi-day, working workshop. The outcomes from the workshop will be a collection of recommendations and ideas for the future of cybersecurity research (over the next 10 years). 

The SaTC v2 workshop and the vision document will help NSF to revamp its flagship cyber security research program through increased partnerships and collaboration among academia, industry, government, and to achieve NSF’s long-term goal of increasing diversity to improve the well-being of traditionally underrepresented individuals in society, improving national security and enhancing our nation’s competitiveness, and building a better infrastructure for research and education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) Program of the National Science Foundation has been around for about decade. The PIs effort in this project was focused on highlighting the accomplishments of the program, collecting data from the community (across academia, government, and industry) to assess the key research challenges and opportunities of the cyber security and privacy community for the next decade.  The outcome was a summary, and a report that was shared with NSF and the broader community.

The open source report can be found online

https://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00623  

The effort began with pre-planning and information gathering activities, followed by a 2 day working workshop on Mar 9-10 2023 held in Dallas. The outcomes from the workshop included a collection of recommendations and ideas for the future of cybersecurity research over the next 10 years. The PIs used this feedback to form a strategy document including summary and detailed reports for the various subjects.

 This is called the vision document for NSF SaTC (2.0).  We hope that the document which includes the feedback from the broader community shall be leveraged to form the vision for future calls for proposals and in some measure direct the next decade of cyber-security research for the NSF and other funding/government/polocy agencies.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/26/2024
Modified by: Farinaz Koushanfar
